modeling vs modelling:

In American English, the verb model becomes modeled and modeling. Outside North America, the preferred participles are modelled and modelling, with two lâ€˜s. Canadians prefer the double-l forms, though the single-l forms appear about a third of the time. (In contrast, the double-l forms are almost nonexistent in 21st-century American writing, and the single-l forms are similarly rare outside North America.) These spelling preferences extend to modeler (U.S.) and modeller (outside the U.S.).
US spelling and grammar conventions are our agreed convention given that our path to standardization is via ANSI
